awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Nearshore Sound Propagation of and Species Response to Active-Source Seismic Surveys
awd_abstract_narration:
During a high energy geophysical survey along the Cascadia Subduction Zone, measurements of sound pressure and particle motion will be made to investigate potential impacts of sound on fishes and invertebrates. Using a vector sensor array, which is an underwater listening device used to detect sounds in water, the PIs would use this data to assess behavioral responses of rockfishes (Sebastes spp), Dungeness crab, and longnose skate to the sound resulting from the geophysical survey.  This survey provides a unique opportunity to characterize ocean noise and investigate the responses of nearshore Northeast Pacific species.  The results of this project would be of scientific interest to advance understanding of the energetics of acoustic propagation and responses of marine species to geophysical surveys.

A vector sensor array will be used to provide in-situ measurements of acoustic particle motion and pressure amplitude levels as a quantifiable description of the environmental acoustic stress induced by the seismic survey. This approach will enable the PIs to evaluate changes in the bioacoustic soundscape during and after the seismic survey relative to pre-survey conditions. This study will be an opportunity to obtain valuable and relatively unique nearshore acoustic data from a seismic sound source that can be used to validate and improve sound propagation models in these challenging nearshore coastal areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An NSF-sponsored geophysical survey along the Cascadia Subduction Zone was conducted in summer 2021, collecting marine seismic data via an array of 36 airguns as an energy source. Few data are available on the in situ individual responses of temperate fishes and invertebrates to seismic surveys, particularly the particle motion aspect. This event provided a unique opportunity to characterize ocean noise parameters and investigate the responses of nearshore NE Pacific species to substantial and sudden alterations to the regional soundscape. We deployed an integrated vector sensor array (NoiseSpotter) to measure both the pressure and the particle motion components of the acoustic disturbance from the seismic survey explosions. We tagged Black and China rockfishes (Sebastes spp.), lingcod, and Dungeness crab, and tracked their movement and behavior (acceleration, depth) in relation to the received sound pressure and particle motion measurements from the airgun pulses. We hypothesized that responses to high-intensity acoustic pulses would depend on the habit (demersal-China rockfish and Dungeness crabs or pelagic-Black rockfish and lingcod) and absence (Dungeness crabs and lingcod) or presence and type (Black and China rockfish) of swim bladder. We conducted our project in Oregon?s Redfish Rocks Marine Reserve where we can exclude potential effects of fishing effort on behavior and where the seismic survey made triplicate passes so we had the opportunity to assess the soundscape and animal behavior before, multiple times during, and after seismic survey activity.

Black rockfish acceleration values were significantly higher on each of the three days the survey vessel was passing the study area compared to the before period. Interestingly, the magnitude of the increase in acceleration compared to the before period decreased with each pass of the seismic survey vessel. For the China rockfish, we detected a significant increase in acceleration only on the day of the first pass of the seismic survey vessel as compared to the before period, not on subsequent survey days. For the black rockfish, while there were more bursts of acceleration in the "during" period, their overall spatial distribution was smaller in the days the seismic survey vessel was in range, with them clustered closer to the rocky structure in the study area. The China rockfish did not move enough to detect any changes in their spatial distributions in relation to the noise from the seismic survey. Of the Dungeness crab we tagged, many left the study area before the seismic survey vessel was in range. Of the six that were present on the first day of the seismic survey, four were not present for the subsequent passes of the vessel but did return later in the season. We are working to determine if we can attribute their behavior to the noise from the survey. Similarly, many of the lingcod were present in May and July but had spotty presence in June when the seismic survey passed. Specifically, three fish were in range for the first pass of the vessel, were out of range for the subsequent passes of the vessel, but did return later in the season. 

The detected effects of the survey vessel noise on rockfish behavior can be used by managers at NSF, BOEM, U.S. and Oregon Departments of Energy, Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW), and NMFS as well as academic scientists leading these expeditions to better assess the cost, benefit, and potential mitigation techniques for future seismic surveys and other noise-producing projects. These findings will contribute to NOAA?s Ocean Noise Strategy and inform the Pacific Fishery Management Council about acoustic impacts on Essential Fish Habitat and managed resources. While we may not yet be able to draw conclusions about the direct effects of noise on the lingcod and Dungeness crab, data on their movement patterns and behavior before and after the seismic surveys (as well as the behavior of the rockfishes in those periods) can be used by resource managers and fisheries researchers to estimate potential effectiveness of spatial management strategies such as marine reserve placement or various other fishery closure areas.
